spring.why: Freeze-thaw cycles commonly loosen or crack shingles, creating leak paths.
spring.look: Missing, curled, cracked, or displaced shingles.
spring.mistake: Assuming leaks only show up inside.
spring.pro: If multiple shingles are damaged or the roof is steep.
spring.note: Roof damage is often visible from the ground with binoculars.

spring.why: Improper flashing is a leading cause of roof leaks.
spring.look: Rust, gaps, lifted edges, or missing sealant.
spring.mistake: Using caulk instead of proper flashing repair.
spring.pro: If flashing is integrated with roofing materials.
spring.note: Sealants fail; flashing is the real defense.

spring.why: Blocked gutters overflow and damage siding and foundations.
spring.pro: If gutters are high or poorly sloped.

spring.why: Improper discharge directs water toward the foundation.
Negative grading causes foundation moisture intrusion.
spring.note: Slope is more important than soil type.

spring.why: Cracks can indicate movement or moisture problems.
spring.pro: If cracks are widening or offset.
spring.note: Crack pattern matters more than size.

spring.why: Damaged siding allows water and pests inside walls.
Failed seals allow water and air infiltration.
